caption_original:
The Great Lakes region is part of our physical and cultural heritage. We depend on them for drinking water, recreation, transportation, power and economic opportunities. Yet, the demands of a large population in this region have taken their toll over time. The impacts of industrialization, climate change, invasive species and toxic contaminants, among other pressures, are evident.

That‚Äôs why the Government of Canada is investing $44.84 million for the Great Lakes Protection Initiative. http://ow.ly/8gb430gXyh5

Do you remember me? I am a Common Loon and the mascot of the Canadian Wildlife Service at Environment and Climate Change Canada. 

Some time ago, I asked to be named, and you suggested lots of great ones. I chose ‚ÄúKwimu.‚Äù It means ‚Äúspirit bird‚Äù in many Indigenous languages. Did you know that two science weather supersites have been built in Iqaluit and Whitehorse? The weather information required in the North differs from what the population uses in the rest of Canada. For example, blowing snow and ice-fog are critical information for northern communities; more relevant than the temperature and humidity. 

Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs Weather Science team will use the data from the supersites to better understand and support weather forecasts that are more relevant to the needs of the people living in the North. #ArcticScience

Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs Weather Science team will use the data from the supersites to better understand and support weather forecasts that are more relevant to the needs of the people living in the North.

The Peary Caribou, which lives in the high Arctic islands of Nunavut and Northwest Territories, is listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. 

Micheline, a wildlife scientist at Parks Canada, and her team combine Indigenous knowledge and innovative research techniques to study changes in caribou behaviour and diet. This work contributes to species recovery and conservation efforts.

Air pollution is one of the most significant environmental problems affecting our health. It adversely affects our lakes and oceans, and causes acid rain and smog. Some of the air pollution in Canada comes from outside the country. That‚Äôs why Canada just ratified the Gothenburg Protocol, an international agreement to reduce air pollutants. 

Under the Protocol, Canada will continue taking action on air pollution by reducing these dangerous emissions. 

We‚Äôre taking action to provide Canadians with clean air and a healthier environment.

Under the Protocol, Canada will continue taking action on air pollution by reducing these dangerous emissions. We‚Äôre taking action to provide Canadians with clean air and a healthier environment.
